FT571413_rubric_category_3.s:
a) Document Sourcing

Responses earn one point by explaining how or why the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least two documents is relevant to an argument about changes in the domestic United States during the period 19391945. (1 point)

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

  • According to Document 5, Black soldiers were treated as less than White soldiers just like in real American society and the Jim Crow laws continued on base. The authors point of view of being a Black soldier shows that he knows best what was happening among races in the army.

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

  • This patriotism is advocated by the Office of War Information who urge women to fill the jobs left behind by soldiers in order to support the war effort and make U.S. victory come sooner (4). The purpose of this is to promote the war effort at home through propaganda.

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

  • Womens role in the home front changed, to become more involved. Many of the men were away fighting the war. This left openings in jobs for women. The government even encouraged women to work. A poster from a government agency promises women that if they work the United States will win the war sooner. (4)

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents audience:

  • Most of the male workers had gone to fight in the war, leaving the industries that fueled America and its military without workers. This forced women to take responsibility and join the workforce. The government also encouraged this through flyers such as the aforementioned poster. The intended audience of these posters were women across the country who sought to change their way of life.

b) Demonstrating Complex Understanding

Responses earn one point by demonstrating a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence, of the change in the domestic United States from 1939 to 1945. (1 point)

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

Demonstrating a complex understanding for this prompt might include the following:

  • Arguing that, while many women entered the workforce to support the war effort, experiencing newfound independence in manufacturing jobs traditionally held by men, American film and media continued to emphasize more traditional gender roles for women

  • Arguing that the wartime experience of mobilizing new workers to replace men who went to combat and of avoiding political protest and dissent in favor of national unity was not very different from the effects of previous wars on the home front

  • Arguing that the reaction of the United States to perceived domestic threats during the war (i.e., Japanese internment) and the curtailment of civil liberties was not different than earlier times of national emergency (e.g., Alien and Sedition Acts in the 1790s, Sedition Act during the First World War)

  • Arguing that, despite the implementation of wartime rationing, economic growth and full employment fostered by the United States mobilization for the war generated increased household savings and pent-up consumer demand that would contribute to a dramatic postwar boom

  • Arguing that, despite the drive to end discrimination against African Americans and to expand civil rights, racial segregation continued and in some ways was strengthened in the United States during the war, revealing a gap between the ideals and realities of democracy

Example of demonstrating complex understanding:

  • During the war, as in all wars, the government exerted a much greater influence on the economy and the citizenry than during peacetime. The War Production Board set prices for industry, and the Office of War Information produced propaganda to rally support for the war effort. (This propaganda was crucial, because, as proven by the immense backlash to the Vietnam War in the 1960s, wars must be fought with the support of the public and with clearly defined and communicated goals in order for them to succeed.) Just as in World War I, taxes were raised and Liberty Bonds were sold to the public to generate additional revenue for fighting the war. However, unlike World War I, a rationing system was imposed to curb consumption of much-needed goods (in World War I, rationing had been done on a voluntary basis). President Roosevelt imposed a selective service system (a draft), which added to the size of the military. Newspapers such as the Washington Post tried to advocate for cheerful compliance with the draft as the fairest method by which an army of the size we need can be recruited (1). All of these examples prove that the U.S. government dramatically grew in power during World War II.

Student earns 0 of 2 point(s)

a) Document Sourcing

Responses earn one point by explaining how or why the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least two documents is relevant to an argument about changes in the domestic United States during the period 19391945. (1 point)

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

  • According to Document 5, Black soldiers were treated as less than White soldiers just like in real American society and the Jim Crow laws continued on base. The authors point of view of being a Black soldier shows that he knows best what was happening among races in the army.

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

  • This patriotism is advocated by the Office of War Information who urge women to fill the jobs left behind by soldiers in order to support the war effort and make U.S. victory come sooner (4). The purpose of this is to promote the war effort at home through propaganda.

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

  • Womens role in the home front changed, to become more involved. Many of the men were away fighting the war. This left openings in jobs for women. The government even encouraged women to work. A poster from a government agency promises women that if they work the United States will win the war sooner. (4)

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents audience:

  • Most of the male workers had gone to fight in the war, leaving the industries that fueled America and its military without workers. This forced women to take responsibility and join the workforce. The government also encouraged this through flyers such as the aforementioned poster. The intended audience of these posters were women across the country who sought to change their way of life.

b) Demonstrating Complex Understanding

Responses earn one point by demonstrating a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence, of the change in the domestic United States from 1939 to 1945. (1 point)

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

Demonstrating a complex understanding for this prompt might include the following:

  • Arguing that, while many women entered the workforce to support the war effort, experiencing newfound independence in manufacturing jobs traditionally held by men, American film and media continued to emphasize more traditional gender roles for women

  • Arguing that the wartime experience of mobilizing new workers to replace men who went to combat and of avoiding political protest and dissent in favor of national unity was not very different from the effects of previous wars on the home front

  • Arguing that the reaction of the United States to perceived domestic threats during the war (i.e., Japanese internment) and the curtailment of civil liberties was not different than earlier times of national emergency (e.g., Alien and Sedition Acts in the 1790s, Sedition Act during the First World War)

  • Arguing that, despite the implementation of wartime rationing, economic growth and full employment fostered by the United States mobilization for the war generated increased household savings and pent-up consumer demand that would contribute to a dramatic postwar boom

  • Arguing that, despite the drive to end discrimination against African Americans and to expand civil rights, racial segregation continued and in some ways was strengthened in the United States during the war, revealing a gap between the ideals and realities of democracy

Example of demonstrating complex understanding:

  • During the war, as in all wars, the government exerted a much greater influence on the economy and the citizenry than during peacetime. The War Production Board set prices for industry, and the Office of War Information produced propaganda to rally support for the war effort. (This propaganda was crucial, because, as proven by the immense backlash to the Vietnam War in the 1960s, wars must be fought with the support of the public and with clearly defined and communicated goals in order for them to succeed.) Just as in World War I, taxes were raised and Liberty Bonds were sold to the public to generate additional revenue for fighting the war. However, unlike World War I, a rationing system was imposed to curb consumption of much-needed goods (in World War I, rationing had been done on a voluntary basis). President Roosevelt imposed a selective service system (a draft), which added to the size of the military. Newspapers such as the Washington Post tried to advocate for cheerful compliance with the draft as the fairest method by which an army of the size we need can be recruited (1). All of these examples prove that the U.S. government dramatically grew in power during World War II.

FT571415_rubric_category_0.s:
Responses earn one point by responding to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which religion shaped political ideas in British North America from 1730 to 1783. (1 point) To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

Examples of acceptable theses:

  • The most significant way that religion shaped political ideas in British North America was the influence of the First Great Awakening on the coming of the American Revolution.

  • American political ideas were greatly affected by religion in this period because the idea that all people had rights contributed to the outbreak of the American Revolution.

Examples of unacceptable theses:

  • Religion shaped political ideas in British North America in the 18th century in many ways. (This example largely restates the prompt).

  • The most significant way that religion shaped American political ideas was the American Revolution. (This example does not suggest a line of reasoning about how religion connects to the American Revolution).

FT571415_rubric_category_1.s:
Responses earn one point by describing a broader historical context relevant to the topic of the prompt (1 point). The context can be from before, during, or after the period 1730 to 1783 as long as the response accurately and explicitly connects the context to how religion shaped political ideas in British North America. This point is not awarded for merely a phrase or a reference.

Examples might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • Religious havens and religious toleration in English colonies in the seventeenth century

  • Growth of trans-Atlantic commerce

  • The continued growth of slavery in the eighteenth century

  • Diverse ethnic and religious background of immigrants in British North America

  • Ongoing conflicts between Native Americans and British colonists

  • Emergence and growth of consumer society

  • The Enlightenment

  • Anglicization of British North American colonies

  • The Seven Years War (French and Indian War)

  • The American Revolution

FT571415_rubric_category_3.s:
a) Historical Reasoning

Responses earn one point by using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument that addresses how religion shaped political ideas in British North America from 1730 to 1783. (1 point) The response might still earn the point if the reasoning used in the response is uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.

Examples of using historical reasoning about causation might include the following:

  • The shared experience of religious revivals and evangelical culture in the 1730s and 1740s strengthened connections between people in Great Britain and British American colonists.

  • The evangelical Christianity shared by many British American colonists encouraged them to embrace common political ideas about rights, equality, and the legitimate exercise of authority.

OR

b) Complexity

Responses earn two points by demonstrating a complex understanding of how religion shaped political ideas in British North America from 1730 to 1783, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence. (2 points)

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

Demonstrating complex understanding for this prompt might include the following.

  • Arguing that while evangelical religious ideas contributed to the Patriot movement in the 1760s and 1770s, religious ideas were also used by those colonists who sought to support existing colonial authorities and class hierarchies and to remain loyal to the king

  • Arguing that, although religious ideas contributed to the American Revolution, the Whig leaders who declared independence from Great Britain were more influenced by mostly secular ideas about natural rights drawn from Enlightenment philosophers and about English liberties drawn from English legal scholars

  • Arguing that while the settlement patterns of the British colonies encouraged the acceptance of religious diversity and toleration, imperial conflicts with Spain and France in the eighteenth century also encouraged colonists to embrace Protestant unity and anti-Catholicism

  • Arguing that the role of differing religious ideas in the American Revolution was similar to the role religious conflict between Puritans and supporters of the Church of England played in causing civil conflict in English North American colonies in the seventeenth century.

  • Arguing that the role of differing religious ideas in the American Revolution was similar to the role religious conflict between Puritans and supporters of the Church of England played in causing civil conflict in English North American colonies in the seventeenth century.

Earns 2 of 2 point(s)

a) Historical Reasoning

Responses earn one point by using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument that addresses how religion shaped political ideas in British North America from 1730 to 1783. (1 point) The response might still earn the point if the reasoning used in the response is uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.

Examples of using historical reasoning about causation might include the following:

  • The shared experience of religious revivals and evangelical culture in the 1730s and 1740s strengthened connections between people in Great Britain and British American colonists.

  • The evangelical Christianity shared by many British American colonists encouraged them to embrace common political ideas about rights, equality, and the legitimate exercise of authority.

OR

b) Complexity

Responses earn two points by demonstrating a complex understanding of how religion shaped political ideas in British North America from 1730 to 1783, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence. (2 points)

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

Demonstrating complex understanding for this prompt might include the following.

  • Arguing that while evangelical religious ideas contributed to the Patriot movement in the 1760s and 1770s, religious ideas were also used by those colonists who sought to support existing colonial authorities and class hierarchies and to remain loyal to the king

  • Arguing that, although religious ideas contributed to the American Revolution, the Whig leaders who declared independence from Great Britain were more influenced by mostly secular ideas about natural rights drawn from Enlightenment philosophers and about English liberties drawn from English legal scholars

  • Arguing that while the settlement patterns of the British colonies encouraged the acceptance of religious diversity and toleration, imperial conflicts with Spain and France in the eighteenth century also encouraged colonists to embrace Protestant unity and anti-Catholicism

  • Arguing that the role of differing religious ideas in the American Revolution was similar to the role religious conflict between Puritans and supporters of the Church of England played in causing civil conflict in English North American colonies in the seventeenth century.

FT571417_rubric_category_0.s:
Responses earn one point by responding to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which regional identities shaped the political development of the United States from 1800 to 1848. (1 point) To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

Examples of acceptable theses:

  • The most significant way that the emergence of regional identities shaped American political development was through westward migration and the creation of new frontier communities, which encouraged territorial expansion in the west and the extension of White male democracy.

  • The emergence of a distinct Southern point of view that focused on cotton plantations and slavery contributed to differing sectional views between 1800 and 1848 about expanding the United States westward.

  • The most significant way that the emergence of regional identities shaped American political development was by provoking calls by nationalists such as Henry Clay for internal improvements in order to facilitate greater connections within the country and overcome sectional divisions.

  • The emergence of regional identities in the period 1800 to 1848 sharpened tensions within and among American political parties over how best to advance national interests and to improve the lot of the common man.

  • The emergence of regional identities led to the formation of new political parties and party platforms in the period 1800 to 1848.

Examples of unacceptable theses:

  • The emergence of regional identities shaped the political development of the United States from 1800 to 1848 in many ways. (This example largely restates the prompt).

  • "The most significant way that the emergence of regional identities shaped American political development was the election of Andrew Jackson. (This mentions the term regional identities but does not suggest a line of reasoning about how Andrew Jacksons election was shaped by them or why it was significant).

FT571417_rubric_category_1.s:
Responses earn one point by describing a broader historical context relevant to the topic of the prompt (1 point). The context can be from before, during, or after the period 1800 to 1848 as long as the response accurately and explicitly connects the context to how religion shaped American political ideas. This point is not awarded for merely a phrase or a reference.

Examples might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • Cotton plantations; expansion of slavery in South and old Southwest

  • Westward expansion; filibustering; American Indian removal

  • The market revolution

  • Early industry, particularly in New England

  • Commerce, particularly in ports such as New York City

  • The sectional crisis of the 1850s

  • The Second Great Awakening (Burned-over district in New York)

  • Anti-slavery/abolitionist movements

  • Antebellum reform movements

  • Womens rights movement/Seneca Falls

FT571418_rubric_category_0.s:
Responses earn one point by responding to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the topic. (1 point) To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the

prompt rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

Examples of acceptable theses:

  • The most significant way that debates over religious or moral values shaped political ideas was in the Republican Partys adoption and promotion of culturally conservative, traditional values during the 1970s through the 1990s.

  • The most significant way that debates over religious or moral values shaped political ideas was in the growing belief that liberalism had led to an overly-permissive and morally lax society.

  • Debates over moral values led many Americans to shift their support from the Democratic to the Republican Party in the period 1960 to 2000.

Examples of unacceptable theses:

  • Debates over religious or moral values shaped political ideas in many ways from 1960 to 2000. (This example largely restates the prompt).

  • The development of computers and cell phones transformed religious and moral values from 1960s to 2000. (This touches on religion and moral values but does not suggest a line of reasoning about how they affected political ideas).

To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d:
Response earns 0/1 point(s)

The thesis must make a historically defensible claim that establishes a line of reasoning about how trans-Atlantic exchanges affected colonial culture in British North America in the period from 1700 to 1770.

Examples that earn this point include:

  • The ideas exchanged across the Atlantic as part of the Enlightenment and the First Great Awakening had a major impact on colonial culture.

  • Trans-Atlantic exchanges had a major effect on colonial culture because of the ways they shaped colonial economies, social structures, and politics.

  • Wealth generated by trans-Atlantic exchanges shaped colonial culture by creating an elite of merchants and plantation owners.

Response earns 1/1 point(s)

Describes a broader historical context relevant to the prompt. (1 point)

To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

o.d:
To earn this point, the response must accurately describe a context relevant to the ways in which trans-Atlantic exchanges affected colonial culture in British North America in the period from 1700 to 1770.

Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration.

  • Columbian Exchange

  • Early settlement patterns of the British colonists

  • The American Revolution

  • Metacoms War

  • Common Sense

  • Transition from indentured to enslaved labor in the Chesapeake

  • United States foreign trade in the early republic

Examples of statements of context that earn the point:

  • Transatlantic exchange started back in the 1500s when the Columbian Exchange moved new plants and diseases to America.

Response earns 2/2 point(s)

Examples of evidence used might include:

  • Navigation Acts extended (Hat Act, Molasses Act, Iron Act)

  • Salutary neglect

  • Seven Years War (French and Indian War)

  • Proclamation of 1763

  • Pontiacs Rebellion

  • Sugar Act

  • Triangular trade

  • Cash crops

  • Slave trade, Middle Passage (slave rebellions Stono Rebellion), Black Codes

Responses earn two points by using at least two examples of specific historical evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.

Example of a statement that would contribute to earning one point for use of evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt:

  • By preaching first in England and then traveling across the Atlantic to British America and preaching there, Protestant minister George Whitefield helped transfer religious ideas from Europe to the American colonies and changed colonial culture. (Statement that uses evidence to support an argument about how trans-Atlantic exchanges of religious ideas shaped colonial culture)

  • British attempts to control trans-Atlantic trade through laws like the Sugar Act led to increased cultural acceptance of illegal activities like smuggling. (Statement that uses evidence to support an argument about how colonial resistance to British mercantilist policies shaped colonial cultural norms)

  • "In the Chesapeake, trade for cash crops like tobacco led to the growth of a wealthy colonial elite. (Statement that uses evidence to support an argument about how the wealth generated by trans-Atlantic exchanges shaped colonial social structures)

FT580880_rubric_category_3.s:
Historical Reasoning: Uses historical reasoning (e.g., comparison, causation, continuity and change over time) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt. (1 point)

To earn the first point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.

OR

Complex Understanding: Demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence. (2 points)

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d:
Response earns 0/2 point

Examples of using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument might include: Explaining how the Great Awakening affected colonial culture

Explaining how the Enlightenment affected colonial culture

Explaining how commercial exchanges of goods from Britain to the American colonies affected colonial culture

Explaining how slavery and the slave trade affected colonial culture

OR

Demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • Explaining a nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables by, for example, examining several colonial regions (changing cultural identities between the regions)

  • Explaining multiple causes or explaining both causes and effects, for example, explaining how colonial culture in the British North American colonies exhibited various features of independence and self-governance, while also expressing aspects of loyalty to the British Crown

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods, for example, examining the long-term effects of slavery on racial tensions

  • Confirming the validity of an argument by corroborating multiple perspectives across themes

  • Qualifying or modifying an argument by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence by, for example, explaining how other factors were more important than the trans-Atlantic exchanges in shaping colonial culture

  • Explaining the various effects of slavery and the slave trade on the development of regional identities

Response earns 1/2 points

Examples of using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument might include: Explaining how the Great Awakening affected colonial culture

Explaining how the Enlightenment affected colonial culture

Explaining how commercial exchanges of goods from Britain to the American colonies affected colonial culture

Explaining how slavery and the slave trade affected colonial culture

OR

Demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • The response argues that the affect of trans-Atlantic exchanges on colonial culture varied by region. It contrasts the creation of a planter elite in the Chesapeake colonies through cash crop cultivation and the slave trade with the growth of a merchant elite in New England through ship building and the triangle trade. (Explaining relevant and insightful connections across geographical areas)

  • The response argues that trans-Atlantic exchanges fostered closer cultural connections between Great Britain and the colonies through colonial consumption of consumer goods, such as tea, while also laying the foundations for separation through disagreements over trade such as conflict over the Townshend Acts. (Explaining multiple effects)

  • The response argues that trans-Atlantic exchanges contributed to colonial unity. It does this through a nuanced discussion of the cultural effect of the Great Awakening and the Enlightenment that contributed to common colonial religious and political understandings and of the economic effect of the triangle trade that led to common colonial dependence on goods imported from Great Britain. (Explaining multiple themes to explore nuance)

The thesis must make a historically defensible claim that establishes a line of reasoning about how immigration affected United States culture in the period from 1840 to 1898.

Examples that earn this point include:

  • Immigration greatly affected culture in the United States from 1840 to 1898 by causing manufacturing to increase, discontent of Americans, and an overall change in the population, especially in cities.

  • This influx of immigration had a significant influence on United States culture from 1840 to 1898 as it caused a reaction through nativist movements, created a new labor force for manufacturing, and ultimately led to the formation of unions.

  • Between 1840 and 1898 increasing tensions between immigrants and nativists shaped the culture of the United States.

o.d:
Response earns 0/2 point(s)

Examples of using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument might include:

  • Explaining how immigration fostered the creation of ethnic communities and how ethnic cultures shaped other cultures

  • Explaining how immigration contributed to the rise of nativist ideas and nativism

  • Explaining how immigration contributed to urbanization and urban challenges

  • Explaining how immigration contributed to a working class culture

OR

Demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • Explaining a nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables by, for example, examining multiple immigrant groups

  • Explaining multiple causes or explaining both causes and effects by, for example, explaining how the influence of immigration generated nativist sentiment in the United States, while at the same time creating an increasingly ethnically diverse culture

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods by making comparisons with the effects of immigration after 1898

  • Confirming the validity of an argument by corroborating multiple perspectives across various immigrant groups and/or various American political and social platforms.

  • Qualifying or modifying an argument by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence by, for example, arguing and explaining how other factors were more important than immigration in shaping United States culture.

Response earns 1/2 point(s)

Examples of using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument might include:

  • Explaining how immigration fostered the creation of ethnic communities and how ethnic cultures shaped other cultures

  • Explaining how immigration contributed to the rise of nativist ideas and nativism

  • Explaining how immigration contributed to urbanization and urban challenges

  • Explaining how immigration contributed to a working class culture

OR

Demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • Arguing that responses to immigration by native-born citizens differed during this period, but most Americans still believed in the superiority of United States culture. It discusses how some Americans, like the Know-Nothings, argued for immigration restriction while others, such as Jane Addams, argued for aid to immigrants in need. It points out that even those who argued for aid still believed in assimilation, rather than multiculturalism. (The response explains multiple perspectives to explore nuance)

  • Arguing that the effect of immigration on United States culture varied by region. It compares immigrations influence on areas with relatively high immigrant populations, like the Northeast and West, which underwent significant economic change, with its influence on areas with relatively low immigrant populations, like the South, whose economies remained primarily agricultural. (The response explains insightful connections across geographical areas)

  • Arguing that responses of native-born citizens to immigration differed during this period. It discusses how some Americans, like the Know-Nothings, argued for immigration restriction while others, such as Jane Addams and other supporters of the settlement house movement, argued for aid to immigrants in need. It then qualifies this argument by pointing out that at this time most Americans, regardless of their perspective on immigration, held similar perspectives that asserted the superiority of United States culture and advocated assimilation rather than multiculturalism. (The response explains how at least four pieces of specific and relevant evidence support a nuanced argument)

  • Arguing that the effect of immigration on United States culture varied by region. It compares immigrations influence on areas with relatively high immigrant populations, like the Northeast and West, which underwent significant economic change, with its influence on areas with relatively low immigrant populations, like the South, whose economies remained primarily agricultural.   • Arguing that responses of native-born citizens to immigration differed during this period. It discusses how some Americans, like the Know-Nothings, argued for immigration restriction while others, such as Jane Addams and other supporters of the settlement house movement, argued for aid to immigrants in need. (This response uses evidence to support an argument about how economic growth did not affect the culture of all Americans equally)

  • Some Americans rebelled against the prosperity homogeneity brought by sustained economic growth during the 1950s and 1960s, joining a counterculture that emphasized rebellion and non-conformity. (This response uses evidence to support an argument about how some groups rebelled against the mass culture created during an era of prosperity)

FT580882_rubric_category_3.s:
Historical Reasoning: Uses historical reasoning (e.g., comparison, causation, continuity and change over time) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt. (1 point)

To earn the first point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.

OR

Complex Understanding: Demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence. (2 points)

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d:
Response earns 0/2 point(s)

Examples of using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument might include:

  • Explaining how economic growth contributed to suburban culture

  • Explaining how sustained economic growth contributed to popular demands for expanded social or political rights

OR

Demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • Explaining a nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables by, for example, exploring racial or ethnic variations in United States culture or by exploring how economic growth affected groups differently

  • Explaining multiple causes such as several particular aspects of economic growth or explaining both causes and effects

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods such as making comparisons with economic growth in the 1920s

  • Confirming the validity of an argument by corroborating multiple perspectives across themes by demonstrating that the development of the counterculture was spurred by a general culture of conformity, itself a product of sustained economic growth

  • Qualifying or modifying an argument by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence by, for example, arguing how other factors were more important than sustained economic growth in shaping United States culture in the period 1940 to 1970

The response does not accomplish the task set by this part of the question:

ONE point for describing ONE specific historical difference between the United States experience in the Korean War and in the Vietnam War

Examples of responses to (b) that would earn credit:

North Koreas invasion of South Korea prompted a United States and United Nations action to drive the North Koreans out, while in Vietnam the United States intervened because of the defeat of the French and the division of Vietnam decided at the peace conference.

United States intervened in South Vietnam to build a government that would serve as an alternative to the Communist North Vietnam; US provided funds and support for the South Vietnamese regime against North Vietnam and the Viet Cong.

Soldiers wartime experience, especially of guerilla warfare, differed in Vietnam.

United States experience in Korea validated, to some extent, the concept of containing communism, while the experience and United States loss in Vietnam ultimately undermined the concept of containment and preventing the domino effect.

Domestic differences may include the more dramatic opposition to involvement in Vietnam as well as the diversion of energy and funds from domestic programs such as the Great Society.

NOTE: Credited responses must address both the Korean War and the Vietnam War, but can imply the other with comparative qualifiers (such as Vietnam was more divisive thus implying than Korea) and describe more than vague generalizations.

The response does not accomplish the task set by this part of the question:

ONE point for explaining specific historical effect of either the Korean War or the Vietnam War on United States society

Examples of responses to (c) that would earn credit:

NOTE: Response may use the same example in c as b, BUT earns the point only with additional development of the example.

Korean War

o Confirmed domestic anxieties about the threat of communism and the Soviet Union and China

o Led to a sustained period of Cold War tensions

o Extended use of the Selective Service System (the draft) from 1950 through the 1960s and the service of millions in the Armed forces at home and abroad in this period

Vietnam War

o Anti-war protest movement in the United States developed in response to United States involvement in Vietnam

o Young people protested the military draft

o Growing divide in the United States between traditionalists/conservatives/older Americans and leftists/radicals/younger Americans

o Led to neglect of domestic programs such as Great Society, the downfall of the Lyndon Johnson presidency in 1968, and public distrust of government (credibility gap)

The thesis must make a historically defensible claim that establishes a line of reasoning about change in United States foreign policy in the period 1783 to 1828.

Examples that earn this point include:

Throughout this entire period the United States foreign policy of neutrality in European affairs remained mostly unchanged.

The United States sought to remain neutral and confront domestic issues throughout this period, but the nations foreign policy underwent major change as the nation became more dependent on international trade and more intertwined in the tension between Great Britain and France.

The conflict in Europe led to changes in United States foreign policy between 1783 and 1828.

To earn one point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three of the documents.

OR

Evidence Beyond the Documents:

To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

FT649699_rubric_category_3.s:
Sourcing: For at least two documents, explains how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument (1 point)

To earn this point, the evidence must explain how or whyrather than simply identifyingthe documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the three documents sourced.

Complexity: Demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence. (1 point)

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d:
Response earns 0/1 point(s)

See document summaries page for examples of possible explanations of the relevance of sourcing.

Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that differing perspectives on relations with Great Britain conflicts shaped United States foreign policy. It discusses Northern Federalists reliance on trade with Great Britain as a reason they wanted to avoid supporting France and contrasts that with support from United States settlers in the West for war with Great Britain, as they blamed British aid for conflicts with Native Americans. (Explains connections across geographic areas)

The response argues that United States foreign policy between 1783 and 1828 differed dramatically from foreign policy during the late 1800s. It contrasts efforts to remain neutral in conflicts such as warfare between Great Britain and France in the 1790s and early 1800s with wars fought in the late 1800s, such as the Spanish American War, to gain imperial possessions. (Explains connections across time periods)

The response argues that United States foreign policy towards European and non-European nations differed dramatically. It uses Documents 1 and 7 as evidence of the United States intention to avoid European conflicts. It then argues that these documents do not acknowledge United States conflicts with Native American nations, as evidenced by Documents 2 and 4, such as Tecumsehs War and the Seminole Wars. (Uses documents and evidence beyond the documents to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives)

o.d:
The response does not accomplish the task set by this part of the question:

ONE point for describing one major difference between Potters and Holts historical interpretations of the Civil War

Examples of responses to (a) that would earn credit:

Potter argues that the Civil War was a continuation of the sectionalism and conflict that characterized United States politics since the creation of the nation, and, thus, it was not a change or break from the past.

In contrast, Holt contends that the Civil War represented an unprecedented breakdown of United States politics, a sharp contrast to the general consensus in the political system in the period prior to the outbreak of the war.

Credited responses must explicitly address the substance of both excerpts.

FT6612_rubric_category_0.s:
The thesis may be a diplomatic thesis, a military thesis, or a combination of both:

  • A diplomatic thesis would agree with the statement, although the emphasis it places on intimidation, on control and on the danger from the Soviet Union may vary from essay to essay.

  • A military thesis would disagree with the statement and stress the desire to force Japans unconditional surrender to save American lives.

  • A combination thesis would argue for a combination of diplomatic and military reasons.

VH015039_rubric_category_0.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent of change in ideas about emancipation during the Civil War. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

Union goals changed a great deal during the Civil War. At the beginning of the war, the primary goal was to preserve the Union. By the end, however, the emancipation of slaves became the central goal.

The question of slavery and the Union goal of abolition were key issues throughout the Civil War. For many people, emancipation remained a priority that changed very little over the course of the war.

During the Civil War, Abraham Lincoln increasingly adopted the idea of emancipating enslaved people in order to undermine the Confederacy, win the war, and preserve the Union.

VH015039_rubric_category_1.s:
To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the extent of change in ideas about emancipation during the Civil War.

The response describes a broader historical context relevant to the extent of change in ideas about emancipation during the Civil War.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration.

Slavery was a key source of sectional division in the nineteenth century.

The acquisition of new territory after the Mexican-American War heightened questions about whether slavery would be allowed in new western lands.

The Souths economy relied on enslaved African American laborers to produce profitable crops like cotton.

Southern states seceded from the Union following the election of Abraham Lincoln as president, which contributed to the beginning of the Civil War.

Most of the Civil War was fought in Southern territory, disrupting Southern plantations and farms and allowing large-scale escapes by enslaved persons.

The first years of the war went poorly for the North; military necessity helped motivate emancipation of enslaved men to assist the war effort.

African American troops were important to the Union victory in the war, both providing large numbers of soldiers and inflicting a symbolic blow to Confederate efforts to preserve slavery.

Pressures on Lincoln from anti-slavery advocates and Radical Republicans in Congress to abolish slavery increased during the period 1860 to 1863.

VH015039_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C1: EVIDENCE  USES THE CONTENT OF THE DOCUMENTS
VH015039_rubric_category_2.s: To earn one point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three of the documents.

o.d: The response does not use the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt.
The response uses the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt. Must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three documents.

VH015039_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: EVIDENCE  SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VH015039_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least three documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
The response uses at least three documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
An example of evidence used to support an argument:

General Mansfields letter shows that many Union leaders favored the abolition of slavery and the emancipation of enslaved people from early stages of the war. Their position on slavery shifted little during the course of the war. (as part of an argument emphasizing continuity and the centrality of the goal of emancipation)

Abraham Lincolns letter to James Conkling shows that he issued the Emancipation Proclamation as part of an ongoing effort to do whatever was necessary to preserve the Union. (as part of an argument emphasizing Lincolns shifting position on slavery and largely practical goals)

VH015039_rubric_category_4.ti: PART C3: EVIDENCE  EVIDENCE BEYOND THE DOCUMENTS
VH015039_rubric_category_4.s:
To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not use at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the prompt.

The response uses at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the prompt.

This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. Typically, statements credited as contextualization will be more general statements that place an argument or a significant portion of it in a broader context.

Statements credited as supporting evidence beyond the documents will typically be more specific details that function as support for a particular point made in an argument, analogous to the function of evidence drawn from the documents.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

Prior to the Civil War, Lincoln was opposed to slavery but not an abolitionist.

General John C. Fremonts proclaimed the military emancipation in Missouri in 1861, which Lincoln revoked (after Fremont refused to do so)

Radical Republicans in Congress such as Senator Charles Sumner and Representative Thaddeus Stevens were highly critical of Lincoln for not doing enough about ending slavery.

Northern Peace Democrats and Copperheads were critical of Lincoln for pursuing war.

Thirteenth Amendment (1865) finally ended slavery.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

Political pressure from Radical Republicans in Congress such as Senator Charles Sumner and Representative Thaddeus Stevens encouraged the federal government to shift toward supporting emancipation.

The process of abolition culminated in the Thirteenth Amendment in 1865, which incorporated the elimination of slavery in the Constitution.

VH441180_rubric_category_0.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which technology transformed the United States economy in the period from 1865 to 1898. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

New technologies fundamentally altered the United States economy in the late nineteenth century by enabling the growth of manufacturing, the large-scale production of goods, innovations in transportation and communication, and the mechanization of agriculture.

In the period 1856 to 1898, technological innovations, such as the application of steam power and electricity, transformed the United States from an agricultural-based to an industrial-based economy.

Although technological innovation in the period 1865 to 1898 changed the nature of many Americans participation in the economy, creating entirely new occupations such as factory worker, telegraph operator, or business manager in a large corporation, many Americans continued to labor in the traditional agricultural and farming work they had always done.

Technological innovation in the period 1865 to 1898 created greater economic interdependence between different regions of the United States and connected the agricultural and industrial sectors of the economy in new ways.

VH441180_rubric_category_1.s:
To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which technology transformed the United States economy in the period from 1865 to 1898.

The response describes a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which technology transformed the United States economy in the period from 1865 to 1898.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

Corporate consolidation and the creation of trusts and holding companies in the period after 1865 allowed for the amassing of capital and resources necessary to establish large-scale industrial enterprises and factories.

The market revolution in the period 1815 to 1850 resulted in the growth of a new wage-based economy, the shift of production of goods out of the home to early factories, and the beginnings of a national market.

The lowered cost and easier access to goods increased the standard of living for many Americans in the late nineteenth century, while a gap between the wealthy and the laboring classes continued to widen.

Federal subsidies and land grants combined with probusiness laissez-faire policies contributed to the growth of corporations and industrial expansion in the period 1860 to 1900.

In the period from 1865 to 1898, economic change resulted in growing conflicts between management and the new industrial workforce, as well as tensions between farmers and the corporate and financial interests that controlled the railroads and the shipment and sale of products to market.

VH441180_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C1: EVIDENCE  USES THE CONTENT OF THE DOCUMENTS
VH441180_rubric_category_2.s: To earn one point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three of the documents.

o.d: The response does not use the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt.
The response uses the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt. Must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three documents.

VH441180_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: EVIDENCE  SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VH441180_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least four documents.
o.af:
An example of evidence used to support an argument:

The article Why We Are an Educated People highlights the idea of American innovationas illustrated by the work of the US Patent Officewhich was the key source of technological development (as part of an argument emphasizing the origins of technological innovation).

The advertisement for the Remington typewriter supports the ways in which technological innovations transformed business communications by replacing writing documents by hand with typing, thereby increasing the numbers of documents and communications that could be produced and creating entirely new occupations in large corporations, such as the typewriter/typist and the clerks needed to manage and organize the many documents and papers (as part of an argument emphasizing how technological innovations facilitated business growth and an industrial economy in the period 1865 to 1898).

The photograph of threshing on a farm north of Shelton, Nebraska, circa 1888, demonstrates how the application of steam power to agriculture, in this instance in a tractor and a threshing machine, transformed and expanded the scale of agricultural production. What had once been a process done by one or two men with a manual implement was now completed by a team of men on a larger and more efficient scale, as evidenced by the many stacks of threshed hay in the background of the image (as part of an argument emphasizing economic transformation by the mechanization of agriculture in the late nineteenth century).

VH441180_rubric_category_4.s:
To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. o.d: The response does not use at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the prompt.

The response uses at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the prompt.

This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. Typically, statements credited as contextualization will be more general statements that place an argument or a significant portion of it in a broader context.

Statements credited as supporting evidence beyond the documents will typically be more specific details that function as support for a particular point made in an argument, analogous to the function of evidence drawn from the documents.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

The Bessemer process or converter (steel production)

Laissez-faire

Andrew Carnegie

Transcontinental railroad

Jay Gould

Cornelius Vanderbilt

J. P. Morgan

Vertical integration, horizontal integration

Continuous processing

McCormick reaper

Grange

Farmers Alliance

Populist Party

Menlo Park, New Jersey

Nikola Tesla

Alternating current

Corliss steam engine

Philadelphia Centennial Exposition, 1876

Chicago Worlds Columbian Exposition, 1893

Agribusiness

Trusts, holding companies

Telephone

Alexander Graham Bell

American Telephone & Telegraph Company (AT&T)

Union Pacific, Central Pacific, Pennsylvania Railroad

Pullman Works

Standard Oil Company

Some examples that would earn credit include:

Events such as the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition in 1876 and the Chicago Worlds Columbian Exposition in 1893 highlighted new technological innovations and disseminated new inventions to the American people.

The vertical integration of production, as adopted by the industrialist Andrew Carnegie, allowed for the corporate control of all aspects of production from the extraction of raw materials such as coal and iron ore to the delivery of the final product, steel. Through this new form of business and industrial organization, Carnegie could control costs, expand production efficiently, and control final supply, pricing, and profits.

Farmers, particularly in the Midwest and West, formed the Populist Party movement in the 1890s in order to challenge the consolidated corporate control of the railroads, which threatened farmers financial independence by charging exorbitant rates for shipping crops to markets.

VH441180_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VH441180_rubric_category_5.s:
To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using six documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt.

The response demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following.

Explaining a nuance by exploring competitions among new technologies, such as between different standards for electrical currents

Explaining similarities and differences in the effect of technology on the economy in other parts of the world and in other periods, such as the Industrial Revolution in England and northwestern Europe in the period 1750 to 1860

Explaining connections to other time periods, such as the way that innovations in transportation changed or altered the United States economy in the first half of the 1800s

Confirming the validity of the responses argument about how technology transformed the United States economy in the period from 1865 to 1898 by explaining how different documents corroborate the argument in spite of differing perspectives among the authors (for example, expertly connecting how the document Why We are an Educated People and Rousiers view in An American Life both celebrate the skill and innovation of the American people, while presenting differing viewpoints on the means by which innovation enables independence and American exceptionalism in contrast to the trajectory of industrialization in Europe)

Qualifying or modifying an argument by considering evidence that shows negative environmental impacts, such as smoke and pollution, of the technologies that transformed the United States economy in the period from 1865 to 1898

Assessing the scope of change in the technology throughout the response, not simply stating its importance

To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
