VR257329_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR257329_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 6]: Terrells point of view was an educated African American reformer, and she was talking about trying to help sharecroppers in the South. Even African American women, who were discriminated against by Jim Crow, were seeking to change things that were unfair to African Americans after Reconstruction. They got an education at the Black colleges like the Hampton Institute and tried to give knowledge to help others who were being treated almost like slaves. This supports my argument that reform changed American society because not just White Progressives were succeeding in making reforms. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the scope and effectiveness of reform movements)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 2]: In document 2 it is a populist party platform that talks how transportation is supposed to be a means for transportation and for the public and that the govt should own it. Also they thought the telegraph should be owned and operated by the government as well because it should be for the public. The purpose of this document is to show that the government needed reform because it should be able to control things that were used by the public. This document shows that reform movements changed the United States socially because people were calling for government intervention in things like railroads and telegraphs because businesses were in charge of those things. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses government and social reform)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 5]: During this time of reform, society in the United States was very corrupt. Boss and machine politics was that of corruption, which included a candidate who basically paid people off to vote for them. They would make sure that they were elected with whatever bribery it took and this included false promises and money. Document five expresses the steps that a reformer must take to avoid this corrupt form of politics. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the need for political reform due to political machines)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 5]: The document talks about how instead of asking the lawmakers to do something about the burden of taxation people should elect new lawmakers that arent corrupt. The intended audience of this document are the people calling for reform and the ones who want a change in tariff policies. This document shows that reform movements changed the US society because people were united and calling for a reform in government. People wanted the lawmakers to do something about tariff policies but the lawmakers were corrupt and they had to elect new ones. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that addresses government reform)

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how reform movements changed United States society in the period from 1877 to 1914.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that reform efforts sought to improve Americans economic status. It then corroborates that argument with evidence about both how federal economic policy sought to stabilize the United States economy and how multiple organized labor unions sought to secure better incomes and working conditions for their members.

The response argues that reform movements sought to improve many Americans lives and protect the most vulnerable Americans. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about the African American experience to show that many reform movements did not address African American concerns. In this context, African Americans established separate, sometimes parallel, reform efforts.

The response argues that while reform movements sought to protect Americans from the worst excesses of industrial society, Progressive reforms actually had a negative impact by expanding the role of government in ways not supported by the Constitution. The response supports this modification of the argument with evidence of government regulation of social mores and the economy.

o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

[Document 3]: This idea of creating a party of the people shows how the lower classes of society were beginning to rise against this corrupt government. As farmers, the Populist party must use railroads to sell their crops. However, the monopolization of railroads caused farmers high prices to sell their crops, which they could not afford. Because of this, the Populist party saw moguls as robber barons, making their opinions on political corruption and the role of moguls in politics negative. (Uses evidence from Document 3 to support an argument about the Populists pushing back against the Robber Barons)

[Document 7]: Crystal Eastman, a social activist, reported the responses of workers, emphasizing the fact that shorter hours would result in lesser work-related injuries. . . . Appealing to the business owners inherent desire for productivity, Eastmans focus on the opinions of average workers allows her to develop an argument for better workers laws, as less work-related injuries means that laborers can work at a higher level of quality. (Uses evidence from Document 7 to support an argument about methods used to bring labor reform)

[Document 3]: This idea of creating a party of the people shows how the lower classes of society were beginning to rise against this corrupt government. As farmers, the Populist party must use railroads to sell their crops. However, the monopolization of railroads caused farmers high prices to sell their crops, which they could not afford. Because of this, the Populist party saw moguls as robber barons, making their opinions on political corruption and the role of moguls in politics negative. (Uses evidence from Document 3 to support an argument about the Populists pushing back against the Robber Barons)

[Document 7]: Crystal Eastman, a social activist, reported the responses of workers, emphasizing the fact that shorter hours would result in lesser work-related injuries. . . . Appealing to the business owners inherent desire for productivity, Eastmans focus on the opinions of average workers allows her to develop an argument for better workers laws, as less work-related injuries means that laborers can work at a higher level of quality. (Uses evidence from Document 7 to support an argument about methods used to bring labor reform)

VR257332_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR257332_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 1]: Through monopolies and interlocking boards of directors, the richest class was able to keep out small competitors and insure a continuing cash flow. This technique was especially prevalent in the railroad, as reflected Jay Goulds testimony before Congress after the purchase of the Kansas Pacific Railway, an action he defended as beneficial and justified (Document 1). Goulds perspective on the issue is muddled by his obvious conflict of interest: as the owner of Union Pacific transcontinental railroad, he would have wanted to paint monopolizing railroad companies in a positive light, as that would legitimize his own approach to business. Needless to say, others were not content with his kind of explanation. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the owner of a monopolizing railroad company)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 3]: One major change during this period was the creation of the Populist party, in James B weaver is depicted on a poster for president. He is addressing the audience of poor American, he wants Equal rights, and special privileges to none. He is fighting for the poor people of America and trying to gain support from them because of his message. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses political reform)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 5]: During this time of reform, society in the United States was very corrupt. Boss and machine politics was that of corruption, which included a candidate who basically paid people off to vote for them. They would make sure that they were elected with whatever bribery it took and this included false promises and money. [The] Document . . . expresses the steps that a reformer must take to avoid this corrupt form of politics (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the need for political reform due to political machines)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 3]: Weavers advertisement is attempting to appeal to his audience and potential voting base, the working class, through iconography of railroads and agricultural tools, since he wanted to protect farmers, and one of the Partys policies was greater government control of railroads. (Provides sourcing regarding audience of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the Populist platform of supporting farmers in their fight against the railroads and the exploitation of the working class by corporate monopolies)

The response explains how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two of the documents.

VR257332_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR257332_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how reform movements changed United States society in the period from 1877 to 1914.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that reform efforts sought to improve Americans economic status. It then corroborates that argument with evidence about both how federal economic policy sought to stabilize the United States economy and how multiple organized labor unions sought to secure better incomes and working conditions for their members.

The response argues that reform movements sought to improve many Americans lives and protect the most vulnerable Americans. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about the African American experience to show that many reform movements did not address African American concerns. In this context, African Americans established separate, sometimes parallel, reform efforts.

The response argues that while reform movements sought to protect Americans from the worst excesses of industrial society, Progressive reforms actually had a negative impact by expanding the role of government in ways not supported by the Constitution. The response supports this modification of the argument with evidence of government regulation of social mores and the economy.

VR258740_rubric_category_2.s:

To earn one point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three of the documents.

o.d: The response does not use the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt.
o.af:
Example of describing the content of a document:

[Document 3]: It was stated that slavery were to gradually be abolished over time. If a child was born from a slave inside the state, that child were to be free however, still serve under their legal owner. The purpose was to make it seem as if they gained some rights, but they still were owned as if they were private property. (Describes evidence from the documents relevant to the topic but do not use that evidence to support an argument)

VR258740_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VR258740_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

[Document 3]: For example, an Act passed in 1799 set new regulations on whether a person was free or a slave. . . . Although this act does not immediately end slavery, it sets up an opportunity in the future to reduce the amount of slavery in the United States. The fact that this document came from the New York state legislature emphasizes that the Northern states are pushing for freedom for slaves. (Uses evidence from Document 3 to support an argument that New York like other northern states was pushing for the freedom of slaves)

[Document 7]: The perception that slavery was a positive good for economic as well as religious reasons was held by many slaveowners and defenders of slaveowners. (Uses evidence from Document 7 to support an argument that the rise in moral objections to slavery during the Second Great Awakening forced the defenders of slavery to articulate new justifications amid rising regional tension over the issue)

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 1]: George Washington, one of our most significant founders, proclaimed his opinion on slavery and in Document 1, it is stated that he owned slaves and would offered rewards to civilians that would find runaway slaves from his own plantation. George Washington was a plantation owner himself and at the time, he did not think anything was wrong with this state of thinking because slavery and the owning of slaves was all society knew and all they thought they would ever know. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the widespread nature of slavery)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 5]: The purpose of Jacobs in Document 5 was to show the inhumanity of slavery in the South to the public and increase antislavery feelings in the North. As more Northerners were influenced by stories of how bad slavery was, sectional tensions increased between the North and the South. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses sectional tensions over slavery as the institution became more embedded in Southern society)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 2]: The historical context surrounding this petition is stirring ideas of Revolution and Independence from the king among white colonists. Because this petition is from 1774, this means colonists were in the midst of fighting for their own freedom from Britain . . . so the ideas of freedom inspired African American slaves to also ask for theirs. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how enslaved Americans sought their freedom alongside white Americans during the period of the Revolution)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 7]: But this document shows the fact that as the 1800s progressed, slavery was no longer seen as a necessary evil; but a positive good. This speech appealed to people like Calhoun who would claim ideas like the benevolent master and that the slaves benefitted from this slavery. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how the increasing division over slavery led to changing justifications for the institution)

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how the institution of slavery changed in the period from 1754 to 1850.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that slavery became more powerful because the relationship between slaveholders and enslaved people became more foundational to southern culture than in the North. It then corroborates that argument with evidence that the southern economy came to depend much more on slave labor through the westward expansion of the cotton industry in the nineteenth century.

The response argues that slavery changed because of the development of cotton cultivation and manufacturing. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that the use of slave labor to produce agricultural crops continued the colonial plantation economy that exported tobacco, rice, and other goods.

The response argues that slavery became more embedded in United States society and its economy by 1850. It then qualifies the argument using evidence about gradual emancipation in the North and the growth of the abolitionist movement.

VR258743_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C1: EVIDENCE  USES THE CONTENT OF THE DOCUMENTS
VR258743_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn one point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three of the documents.

o.d: The response does not use the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt.
o.af:
Example of describing the content of a document:

[Document 1]: We see this in document 1 where a seaport in Virginia is depicted and slaves are working and moving goods while we see their white counterparts over seeing them instead of working alongside them. (Describes evidence from the documents relevant to the topic but does not use that evidence to support an argument)

o.d:
The response uses the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt. The response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least three documents.

VR258743_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VR258743_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

[Document 2]: This superior mindset is evidenced in the law passed by the Georgia colonial legislature, . . . which declared all slaves property, and stripped them of any humanity or rights. Indians were also stripped of their title of human in this document, belittled to the equivalent of property. (Uses evidence from Document 2 to support an argument about the historical continuity of the doctrine of white supremacy as the underlying justification of slavery)

[Document 4]: In it, Coxe describes how cotton production has increased and how it has become more important to international trade and manufacturing. This goes to show how slavery, already accepted in the South prior to the aforementioned invents, has become even more invaluable to the American economy. (Uses evidence from Document 4 to support the argument that the institution of slavery is growing and expanding.)

o.d:
The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least four documents.

Documents used:

VR258743_rubric_category_4.ti: PART C3: EVIDENCE  EVIDENCE BEYOND THE DOCUMENTS
VR258743_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d:

This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. Typically, statements credited as contextualization will be more general statements that place an argument or a significant portion of it in a broader context.

Statements credited as supporting evidence beyond the documents will typically be more specific details that function as support for a particular point made in an argument, analogous to the function of evidence drawn from the documents.

VR258743_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR258743_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 4]: The point of view in Document 4 is of a government official. Since he says we want to grow more cotton and slaves were needed for cotton, this shows that American leaders felt that slavery was important for the U.S. economy. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the growing importance of slavery to the United States economy in the nineteenth century)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 7]: In the diary by Bennet Barrow . . . , there were incredibly strict rules that slaves needed to follow, and this was written in the year 1838. This list shows that was the way people thought because he didnt write it for the purpose of convincing anyone of anything. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how attitudes towards enslaved persons contributed to the harsh controls used on plantations)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 5]: Religious revivals like the Second Great Awakening in the late 1700s mid-1800s sparked reforms such as temperance and abolitionism. Not only did protestants welcome blacks into the religion, they set the stage for advocates of abolitionists. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the rise of abolitionism in the era of reform)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 6]: Since the author is addressing people who have been discriminated against by race like him, it gives him an opportunity to be candid about his feelings. It shows how slavery changed because now blacks began encouraging each other and trying to organize and connect to resist the awful practice of slavery. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the rising voices of opposition to the institution of slavery)

o.d:
The response explains how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two of the documents.

VR258743_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR258743_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how the institution of slavery changed in the period from 1754 to 1850.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that slavery became more powerful because the relationship between slaveholders and enslaved people became more foundational to southern culture than in the North. It then corroborates that argument with evidence that the southern economy came to depend much more on slave labor through the westward expansion of the cotton industry in the nineteenth century.

The response argues that slavery changed because of the development of cotton cultivation and manufacturing. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that the use of slave labor to produce agricultural crops continued the colonial plantation economy that exported tobacco, rice, and other goods.

The response argues that slavery became more embedded in United States society and its economy by 1850. It then qualifies the argument using evidence about gradual emancipation in the North and the growth of the abolitionist movement.

o.d: The response demonstrates a complex understanding of how the institution of slavery changed in the period from 1754 to 1850, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that slavery became more powerful because the relationship between slaveholders and enslaved people became more foundational to southern culture than in the North. It then corroborates that argument with evidence that the southern economy came to depend much more on slave labor through the westward expansion of the cotton industry in the nineteenth century.

The response argues that slavery changed because of the development of cotton cultivation and manufacturing. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that the use of slave labor to produce agricultural crops continued the colonial plantation economy that exported tobacco, rice, and other goods.

The response argues that slavery became more embedded in United States society and its economy by 1850. It then qualifies the argument using evidence about gradual emancipation in the North and the growth of the abolitionist movement.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about how the American Revolution changed society in the period from 1765 to 1800. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

The American Revolution changed American society because it instilled the values of liberty, justice, and unity among much of the population. (Establishes a line of reasoning with analytic categories)

The American Revolution changed American society because it fostered a feeling of unity among the diverse population of the United States. (Establishes a line of reasoning)

VR258831_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VR258831_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

[Document 7]: [This document] comes from a farmer who did not want to pay for the debts from the war. The frustration with taxes coming from the British king was now replaced with frustration with taxes coming from state governments, but there was still frustration with taxes. With no enforcement of state or individual taxation they couldnt provide for these debts. They didnt want to be forced into paying debts and the articles of confederation didnt work in making anything happen. (Uses evidence from Document 7 to support an argument about a continuity in resistance to taxation before and after the war)

[Document 4]: Women had long been living behind the mens shadow, but with the American Revolution, some women like Wilkinson realized that they should be able to be involved in political matters and not only be stuck inside the house due to their nature. . . . While this realization wouldnt led to much in the following couple of decades, it was the start of a bigger fight, womens suffrage. (Uses evidence from Document 4 to support an argument about the pursuit of womens rights)

VR258831_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR258831_rubric_category_5.s: To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 7]: William Manning explains the need to care for the majority instead of the minority when it comes to paying off debts to the minority. Before he was a Democratic-Republican, this farmer was probably an anti-Federalist who distrusted the minority who were in the elite. . . . Manning, as well as other Americans, believed that the central government should care for the majority of the country as opposed to the minority. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of Document 7 regarding an argument about majority rule)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 6]: Mercy Otis Warren . . . used her writings to advocate colonial resistance to British suppression of liberties and rights. Years after the Revolution, she would educate Americans as to the new power of the Constitution, which ultimately leads to early state rights argument. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the growing power of the new federal government)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 1]: As Britain taxed the colonists, issuing the Sugar Acts, Stamp Act, and Townshend Acts, Americans rose in protest. Many political figures, including James Otis, argued that Americans were British citizens, and thus had equal rights under British law (Document 1). The fact that the colonists were being taxed completely without consent and without representation in the British Parliament seemed to appear as a violation of their fundamental rights as British citizens and as equals under the law. This idea of fundamental equality could be tied back to the Enlightenment practices that many founding fathers believed in. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the ideas of taxation without appropriate representation)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 4]: Eliza Wilkinson calls for the blood that has been shed due to the British to not be in vain. Her intended audience was the already outraged colonists who had already been taking action against the British, such as the many brave Americans who stormed the Boston Harbor in 1773 participating in the infamous Boston Tea party, and the many others part of American militias. (Provides sourcing regarding audience regarding an argument about growing antagonism to British authority)

o.d: The response explains how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two of the documents.

VR258831_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR258831_rubric_category_6.s:
To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how the American Revolution changed society in the period from 1765 to 1800.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that the American Revolution effected little change because it left existing social hierarchies for ordinary White men, African Americans, and women in place. It then corroborates that argument with evidence about the ways in which the United States Constitution and the Federalist Party continued to restrict liberty by restraining the political power of the states and ordinary Americans.

The response argues that the American Revolution increased the political power of and economic opportunities for ordinary American compared to the colonial period. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about the continuation of slavery and limitations of revolutionary ideology for women.

The response argues that the American Revolution unleashed a republican ideology that increased the political and social freedoms of many Americans. It then modifies the argument using evidence about developments later in the nineteenth century to argue that the full meaning of revolutionary ideology about natural rights was not fulfilled until later with the expansion of White male suffrage and the abolition of slavery after the Civil War.

VR258891_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR258891_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 4]: George Washington expressed the point of view of an elite political leader and wealthy plantation owner who feared that too much democracy and a weak central government would hurt the United States. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of Document 4 regarding an argument about elite fears about popular misrule in the post-Revolutionary United States)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 5]: Due to their participation in the revolution, from boycotts to fighting in the war as Molly Pitchers, women were starting to be seen as a more important part of society. Benjamin Rush . . . used his writings to advocate on the importance of womens education, as it was pertinent so they could teach their sons how to be a good American when they got older (which followed the principles of Republican Motherhood). Education became an important step for women in changing their status in society after the Revolution. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the gains that women made because of the American Revolution)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 1]: The British had imposed a plethora of taxes upon the Americans, such as the Stamp Act, the Sugar Act, and the Townshend Duties that created taxes on many American goods. Since the Americans had no say in the creations of these taxes, they felt as if they were simply a tool for the benefit of the British Empire. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses that the colonists felt overtaxed by the British)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 7]: The painting featuring George Washington . . . shows the Commander in Chief fully in command. The Whiskey Rebellion was an early test of the new government. The painting shows the respect for the government and the beauty obedience brings to the nation, this painting and news of the suppression of the Whiskey Rebellion encourages the wealthy to have a stake in the government. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that addresses that the painting is to convince its audience that the new government can protect their investments)

VR258891_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR258891_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

VR259032_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VR259032_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

[Document 2]: Document 2, a magazine article from 1853, explains that slavery is key to the economic success of the South, and that if voluntary labor was implemented instead, it would be unsuccessful. Cotton, the key to the Souths economic success, was primarily reaped and sewed by slaves in large plantations. The Souths argument on the subject was that nobody would every simply volunteer to pick cotton for someone elses economic benefit, and therefore slavery was necessary to Southern success. Because of this, and the Norths strong opposition to the subject, the South felt that their way of life was being threatened and that their only option was to succeed from an over-controlling government. (Uses evidence from Document 2 to support an argument about tension between the North and South)

VR259032_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR259032_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 2]: Whilst on the other hand in document 2, a magazine argues that, The slave-labor of the United States, has hitherto conferred and is still conferring the inappreciable blessings on mankind. Such a position was the same for many southerners who argues that slavery was a positive good for America. The magazine which stated this was a southern magazine by the name of American Cotton Planter which makes it easy to see the bias because plantations often ran the media outlets seeing as they were the more politically powerful entities. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how media influenced the larger debate over slavery, creating conflict)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 5]: The North regions believed that the slavery system was unjust and that it did not uphold democratic ideals, like the free-labor system. . . . The purpose of this document is to try to educate people on the hypocrisy of the slave system and put it on the same level as aristocracy in order to foster even more opposition to the slave system. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that regional differences on the issue of slavery created tensions that led to the Civil War)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 3]: Document 3 states The people of the territories shall be allowed to do as they please upon the questions of slavery. What this shows is how congress tried popular sovereignty as well in order to try and keep peace. This would ultimately fail miserably as this would lead to the Bleeding Kansas incident in which there were open fights on the street and people murder during the time in which they were supposed to elect to be a free or slave state. This would be a foreshadowing of what was to come as people could first see how dangerous and real the argument of slave vs free would be. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the larger debate over popular sovereignty and how the ideas put forth in the document ultimately led to unrest in Kansas)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 5]: In Document 4, a United States Senator from New York, illustrates the immorality of slavery by alluding to the Constitution of the United States, and then presents the idea of a free-labor system. As a man from the North who did not rely on slavery as labor for success, it is easy for him to speak condemningly about the immorality of slavery to appeal to his audience. By doing so, he threatened the then Southern way of life and created a moral divide between North and South that does work to contribute to the Civil War. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that disagreements about the nature of free and slave labor fueled discord between regions)

o.d:
The response explains how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two of the documents.

Documents used:
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 2]: Whilst on the other hand in document 2, a magazine argues that, The slave-labor of the United States, has hitherto conferred and is still conferring the inappreciable blessings on mankind. Such a position was the same for many southerners who argues that slavery was a positive good for America. The magazine which stated this was a southern magazine by the name of American Cotton Planter which makes it easy to see the bias because plantations often ran the media outlets seeing as they were the more politically powerful entities. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how media influenced the larger debate over slavery, creating conflict)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 5]: The North regions believed that the slavery system was unjust and that it did not uphold democratic ideals, like the free-labor system. . . . The purpose of this document is to try to educate people on the hypocrisy of the slave system and put it on the same level as aristocracy in order to foster even more opposition to the slave system. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that regional differences on the issue of slavery created tensions that led to the Civil War)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 3]: Document 3 states The people of the territories shall be allowed to do as they please upon the questions of slavery. What this shows is how congress tried popular sovereignty as well in order to try and keep peace. This would ultimately fail miserably as this would lead to the Bleeding Kansas incident in which there were open fights on the street and people murder during the time in which they were supposed to elect to be a free or slave state. This would be a foreshadowing of what was to come as people could first see how dangerous and real the argument of slave vs free would be. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the larger debate over popular sovereignty and how the ideas put forth in the document ultimately led to unrest in Kansas)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 5]: In Document 4, a United States Senator from New York, illustrates the immorality of slavery by alluding to the Constitution of the United States, and then presents the idea of a free-labor system. As a man from the North who did not rely on slavery as labor for success, it is easy for him to speak condemningly about the immorality of slavery to appeal to his audience. By doing so, he threatened the then Southern way of life and created a moral divide between North and South that does work to contribute to the Civil War. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that disagreements about the nature of free and slave labor fueled discord between regions)

VR259032_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR259032_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the causes of the Civil War in the period from 1830 to 1861.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that disagreements over slavery were the main causes of the Civil War. It then corroborates that argument with cultural evidence including the impact of the publication of Uncle Toms Cabin and Southern paternalism and evidence related to foreign policy about the Mexican-American War, arguing that all of these developments emerged from disagreements over slavery and contributed to the Civil War.

The response argues that disagreements over states rights were the main causes of the Civil War, drawing the narrative back to disputes over tariffs in the 1830s. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about the importance of slavery in many of these debates.

The response argues that disagreements over slavery were the main causes of the Civil War. It then modifies the argument using evidence that the rise of industrialization transformed a relatively stable economic system in different ways in the North and in the South, and that it was industrialization that prompted the Civil War to happen when and how it did.

o.d: The response demonstrates a complex understanding of the causes of the Civil War in the period from 1830 to 1861, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that disagreements over slavery were the main causes of the Civil War. It then corroborates that argument with cultural evidence including the impact of the publication of Uncle Toms Cabin and Southern paternalism and evidence related to foreign policy about the Mexican-American War, arguing that all of these developments emerged from disagreements over slavery and contributed to the Civil War.

The response argues that disagreements over states rights were the main causes of the Civil War, drawing the narrative back to disputes over tariffs in the 1830s. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about the importance of slavery in many of these debates.

The response argues that disagreements over slavery were the main causes of the Civil War. It then modifies the argument using evidence that the rise of industrialization transformed a relatively stable economic system in different ways in the North and in the South, and that it was industrialization that prompted the Civil War to happen when and how it did.

VR259168_rubric_category_3.s:

To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

[Document 5]: The Kansas-Nebraska Act attempted to fix this by allowing the people in the state to vote, as seen . . . where President Buchanan expressed his hopes for territorial vote in ending regional divide. Bleeding Kansas, a stem of violence caused by unofficial votes by people from different states who wanted Kansas to be a slave state is an example of a flaw in the system of popular sovereignty. (Uses evidence from Document 5 to support an argument about tension between the North and South)

VR259168_rubric_category_4.ti: PART C3: EVIDENCE  EVIDENCE BEYOND THE DOCUMENTS
VR259168_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not use at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the causes of the Civil War in the period from 1830 to 1861.
o.af:
Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

Abolitionist movementWilliam Lloyd Garrison, John Brown, Harriet Tubman, Harriet Jacobs

Election of 1860

o.d:
The response uses at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the causes of the Civil War in the period from 1830 to 1861.

This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. Typically, statements credited as contextualization will be more general statements that place an argument or a significant portion of it in a broader context.

Statements credited as supporting evidence beyond the documents will typically be more specific details that function as support for a particular point made in an argument, analogous to the function of evidence drawn from the documents.

VR259168_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR259168_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 1]: In a statement by John C. Calhoun to the South Carolina state convention, Calhoun discusses the power of nullification that the states should possess over the Federal Government (Document 1). The idea of nullification stems from the Southern fear that the Federal government only possessed interests favoring the Northern states, which caused the South to champion the ideals of states rights which caused them to ultimately leave the Union with the belief that the Union no longer represented the interests of the Southern states. Calhouns point of view is that the states must possess some form of a check to make sure that the Federal government does not infringe on the jurisdiction and authority of the states. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the Southern reasons for advocating states rights)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 5]: It is also important to take into account that President Buchanan personally did not support the institution of slavery, and it is possible that he phrased his address in this way on purpose in order to denounce slavery as a whole. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that James Buchanan felt motivated to include an implied message about the institution of slavery)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 1]: An example of this support for the negative sentiment leading toward the Civil War is stated through John C. Calhoun during the nullification crisis of 1832 which was a sectional constitutional conflict in the United States during Andrew Jacksons presidency. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the role of the nullification crisis in creating sectional tension)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 2]: In a speech regarding the Fourth of July, Fredrick Douglas states that slaves do not possess the same freedoms and liberties that white people in the United States, and that the Fourth of July has no meaning to slaves (Document 2). A cultural belief of the importance of abolition began to take root in the North as the issue of slavery went beyond just a political issue to one concerning the moral implications of the institution, and lead to the belief that slavery must be abolished as it is immoral and wrong. Douglass purpose with this speech is to cause his audience, likely Northerners and abolitionists, to reflect on the ideals held by America, such as the protection and championing of freedom and liberty, and to wonder whether those ideals are reflected by the country while at the same time maintain an institution that directly goes against those beliefs. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document that addresses an argument about the influence of moral suasion on Northern sentiments about slavery)

o.d:
The response explains how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two of the documents.

Documents used:

VR259169_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VR259169_rubric_category_3.s:

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

[Document 4]: [This document] reflects the pro-slavery sentiment of the South that had a huge impact on the cause of the Civil War. [It] is a court ruling by US Supreme Court Justice Roger Taney on the Dred Scott v. Sanford Supreme Court case. This case ruled that, since their ancestors were imported into America and sold as slaves, African Americans, both free and enslaved, cannot be considered citizens and cannot become a member of the US political community and are not entitled to becoming citizens and acquiring the privileges and rights of American citizens. [It] reflects how strong and divisive the pro-slavery argument and racial superiority ideals that were prevalent in the South was; it demonstrates the Souths unwillingness to comply with anti-slavery laws. (Uses evidence from Document 4 to support an argument about how the Souths defense of slavery contributed to the Civil War)

o.d:

VR259169_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR259169_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 2]: This, once again, highlights the issue of states rights. Clearly, this man, Henry Weeden, was opposed to this law, yet he had to sit back while it was enforced in his own town while he supported the very people that enabled it. It was issues like this, the Fugitive Slave Law, that created turmoil leading up to the Civil War. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how residents of free states, particularly abolitionists, resented the imposition of the Fugitive Slave Law)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 5]: In Picking cotton on a Georgia plantation by Ballous pictorial . . . , it presents countless slaves working in harsh conditions, along with several children being forced to work alongside. This was most likely painted by someone in the North to show the atrocity that slavery has brought upon America and to raise awareness to anger the Northerners to work towards its abolishment. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses opposition in the North against slavery)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 2]: Weedens refusal to fix Freemans clothes happened during the historical situation of the passing of the Fugitive Slave Act in 1850. This forced northerners to return escaped slaves to the South, which made northerners very mad at the south because some of them hated slavery a lot. This helps show how slavery caused sectional tensions that led to the Civil War. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the role of sectional tensions over slavery in causing the Civil War)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 6]: As a Northern journalist, he aims to have his audience realize that the North have built themselves in a more morally-right fashion, while the South rely on an immoral fashion to make profits. These tensions over whether the US should allow slavery became the most important cause of the Civil War. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how Olmstead affirmed Northerners belief in the superiority of their free labor system and indicated how debates about the morality of slavery contributed to tensions between the North and South)

o.d:

VR259169_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR259169_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the causes of the Civil War in the period from 1830 to 1861.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that disagreements over slavery were the main causes of the Civil War. It then corroborates that argument with cultural evidence including the impact of the publication of Uncle Toms Cabin and Southern paternalism and evidence related to foreign policy about the Mexican-American War, arguing that all of these developments emerged from disagreements over slavery and contributed to the Civil War.

The response argues that disagreements over states rights were the main causes of the Civil War, drawing the narrative back to disputes over tariffs in the 1830s. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about the importance of slavery in many of these debates.

The response argues that disagreements over slavery were the main causes of the Civil War. It then modifies the argument using evidence that the rise of industrialization transformed a relatively stable economic system in different ways in the North and in the South, and that it was industrialization that prompted the Civil War to happen when and how it did.

o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 2]: The point of view of Frances Butler Leigh is a former slaveowner within the confederacy who clearly detests the ability of free slaves to vote. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the authors opposition against Black political rights obtained during Reconstruction)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 6]: This can be seen in an address by Ferdinand L. Barnett, which has the purpose of calling for unity among African Americans to fight against education discrimination, a prominent issue during reconstruction. . . . As see in the purpose of this address, discrimination over the issue of fair education influenced America by creating groups and causing debates over the topic. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how leaders worked to keep attention on issues relevant to ending discriminatory practices)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 4]: While the fifteenth amendment banned race-based discrimination to vote under the law, African American men were continuously prevented from voting through things like literacy tests, threats and grandfather clause. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the continuity of opposition to Reconstruction changes in society)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 5]: James T. Rapier makes a speech about the Civil Rights Act of 1875, as an African American congressman from the South. Having a black congressman was incredibly rare at the time following the Civil War, especially in the South, but he was still able to be elected and make a speech to advocate for his people, which could have been dangerous to do before. He targets the rest of the House of Representatives as an audience, educating them on the horrible position of black citizens during the time of Reconstruction. African Americans had been treated horribly, and even though they were free, they were still not equal. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument about the need for congressional action to protect the rights of African Americans)

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how Reconstruction changed United States society in the period from 1865 to 1900.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that Reconstruction didnt change much in United States society because African American political gains were short-lived. It then corroborates that argument with evidence about how the rise of sharecropping represented a loss of economic freedoms gained after the end of slavery and Jim Crow represented a loss of social freedoms.

The response argues that United States society changed because African Americans gained new political and civil rights during Reconstruction. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about new state laws passed during and after Reconstruction that effectively dispossessed African Americans of their civil rights.

The response argues that new constitutional amendments passed during Reconstruction changed United States society by recognizing the rights of African Americans. It then modifies the argument using evidence that African Americans were not able to fully use these rights until after the Civil Rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s.
