VR259378_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR259378_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 1]: Advocacy for black male suffrage spanned across the United States, most especially in liberal and anti-slavery environments, as seen in 1865 at an Ohio educational institution (Doc 1). Seeing that the deliverance of this address was given by an advisor to Abraham Lincoln in a liberal environment (anti-slavery), his condemnation of slavery on a moral (non-political) basis directly contributed to his support of black male suffrage and influenced the educated societal members of the audience. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the support for Black voting rights found both regionally and within Lincolns administration)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 4]: The governor of North Carolina, W.W. Holden, issued proclamations. The things he provided for the state were to cater to the upsurging amount of violence in the south, due to the violence of the Ku Klux Klan. This proclamation was a threat towards those who supplemented the violence, it was an assurance of safety. The proclamation was in essence a righteous move to hold back the KKK. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses responses to violence during Reconstruction)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 7]: A photo at Tuskegee Institute in Alabama displays many African American students in a chemistry lab in 1900. . . . During this time, reconstruction had already ended and federal troops had been pulled out of the south. However, this document shows how these laws still enabled Africans to obtain a higher degree of education which they would have previously not been able to. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses change in society offering increased educational opportunities for African Americans, which persisted long after the end of Reconstruction)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 4]: [This document] is a proclamation by the governor of North Carolina, W. W. Holden, stating that a persons rights must be protected no matter who they are and those who are unlawfully inhibiting the rights of others must be punished. This shows how the emancipation of the blacks was not completely accepted in the U.S. as some southerners still resided in hate for them. The intended audience . . . are groups of white supremacists such as the K.K.K. who continue to discourage blacks in the south. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that some southerners resisted changes even as some politicians protected African American rights)

o.d:

VR259378_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR259378_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how Reconstruction changed United States society in the period from 1865 to 1900.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that Reconstruction didnt change much in United States society because African American political gains were short-lived. It then corroborates that argument with evidence about how the rise of sharecropping represented a loss of economic freedoms gained after the end of slavery and Jim Crow represented a loss of social freedoms.

The response argues that United States society changed because African Americans gained new political and civil rights during Reconstruction. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about new state laws passed during and after Reconstruction that effectively dispossessed African Americans of their civil rights.

The response argues that new constitutional amendments passed during Reconstruction changed United States society by recognizing the rights of African Americans. It then modifies the argument using evidence that African Americans were not able to fully use these rights until after the Civil Rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s.

o.d: The response demonstrates a complex understanding of how Reconstruction changed United States society in the period from 1865 to 1900, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.

The response argues that United States society changed because African Americans gained new political and civil rights during Reconstruction. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about new state laws passed during and after Reconstruction that effectively dispossessed African Americans of their civil rights.

The response argues that new constitutional amendments passed during Reconstruction changed United States society by recognizing the rights of African Americans. It then modifies the argument using evidence that African Americans were not able to fully use these rights until after the Civil Rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the effects of African American internal migration between 1880 and 1930.
o.af:
Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

The effects of the African American internal migration included gaining new economic opportunities and racism by some white people, but the most important effect was more organizing by African Americans for their rights. African American migration had lots of effects, including changes in culture, racial violence, and social activism for civil rights. (Establish a line of reasoning with analytic categories)

More African Americans lived in cities as a result of internal migration. (Establish a line of reasoning)

o.d: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the effects of African American internal migration between 1880 and 1930.
o.af:

The Civil War

Emancipation

Reconstruction/Southern Redemption

Second World War/industrial employment

The Civil Rights movement

Examples that earn this point include:

After the end of the Civil War, Southern plantation owners forced many African Americans to become sharecroppers and eventually many African Americans sought to leave the South for better economic opportunities in the North.

As African Americans faced racial discrimination in the North, they increasingly advocated for civil rights. This advocacy grew in both the North and South after 1930, leading to movements for integration, voting rights, and an end to discrimination.

VR597751_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING

Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 5]: The Atlanta Constitution article, written from the point of view of a southerner worried about losing African American workers, expressed the need for reform to convince African Americans to stay in the South, but as a southern white person in the Jim Crow era, the author did not believe reform required social equality between black and white people. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that African American migration motivated some southerners to call for reform)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 1]: The purpose of John L. Davis article was to encourage African American professionals to migrate to Kansas to provide services to the Black community in the state. This demonstrates that migration led to the creation of new communities that included African Americans in a variety of occupations. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that African Americans migration led to new economic opportunities)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 3]: When Fannie Barrier Williams was writing, African Americans, including women, were creating new communities in northern cities, such as New York or Chicago. They found increased opportunities to organize their own societies to advance reform or, as in Harlem, to engage in artistic and cultural pursuits that werent defined by the standards of white society. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that the most important effect of African American internal migration was the development of pride in Black culture)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 7]: The audience for the article was African Americans living in the North, who sought to assert their rights through organizations such as the NAACP. Increasingly during the Great Migration, African American organized to opposed racial discrimination faced not only in the South, but also in the places in the North where they migrated. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that African American migration led to great Black political activism)

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the effects of African American internal migration between 1880 and 1930.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that the most important effect of African American internal migration was the growth in pride in Black culture in the early 1900s. It then corroborates that argument with relevant and insightful evidence that makes a connection across periods by explaining the migrant populations role in later development including the Black Power movement and their influence on the Civil Rights movement.

The response argues that African Americans gained new economic opportunities in the North. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about how racial discrimination in employment and racial segregation in residential areas of Northern cities limited opportunities for African American migrants.

The response argues that racial discrimination grew in parts of the country where African American migrated between 1880 and 1930. It then modifies the argument with evidence that African American migrants advocating for civil rights launched efforts that ultimately reduced some forms of racial discrimination between the 1950s and the 1970s.

Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that the most important effect of African American internal migration was the growth in pride in Black culture in the early 1900s. It then corroborates that argument with relevant and insightful evidence that makes a connection across periods by explaining the migrant populations role in later development including the Black Power movement and their influence on the Civil Rights movement.

The response argues that African Americans gained new economic opportunities in the North. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about how racial discrimination in employment and racial segregation in residential areas of Northern cities limited opportunities for African American migrants.

The response argues that racial discrimination grew in parts of the country where African American migrated between 1880 and 1930. It then modifies the argument with evidence that African American migrants advocating for civil rights launched efforts that ultimately reduced some forms of racial discrimination between the 1950s and the 1970s.

VR597752_rubric_category_5.ti: Part D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR597752_rubric_category_5.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how the American Revolution contributed to the development of an American national culture from 1776 to 1800.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating complex understanding might include:

The response argues that political ideals helped to foster a common democratic culture. It then corroborates that argument with evidence from multiple variables such as how Enlightenment ideals engaged elites and expanded political participation engaged ordinary people.

The response argues that political ideals helped to foster a common democratic culture. It then qualifies that argument by providing evidence that, despite the common democratic culture, different experiences shaped by racial, regional, or class differences continued to divide Americans.

The response argues that the American Revolution played a minor role in the development of national culture. It then modifies the argument with evidence that Enlightenment ideals in place before the Revolution developed over time and gradually contributed to the emergence of a national culture in the period after the War of 1812.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how federal government actions contributed to United States settlement in the West from 1830 to 1890.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating complex understanding might include:

The response argues that the federal government encouraged western settlement through its land policies, economic policies, and wars against Native Americans. It then corroborates the argument by using evidence from multiple variables to show how land policies, economic policies, and wars against Native Americans were all linked.

The response argues that warfare initiated by the federal government and federal land policies contributed to the settlement of the West. It then qualifies the argument by providing evidence that federal policies were often only the first step. Business interests were generally responsible for encouraging large scale settlement.

The response argues that the federal government encouraged western settlement by offering inexpensive land to White settlers. It then modifies the argument by going on to use examples to argue that, while federal policy was a factor, the action and autonomy of settlers actually drove the settlement process.

Using comparison to discuss similarities and differences between feminist leaders such as Gloria Steinem and Betty Friedan and conservative leaders such as Phyllis Schlafly.

VR597754_rubric_category_5.ti: Part D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR597754_rubric_category_5.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of factors that contributed to changes in womens roles in United States society in the period from 1940 to 2000.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating complex understanding might include:

The response argues that political activism was the primary cause of changes in womens roles. It then corroborates that argument with evidence from multiple activist movements such as the womens rights movement, the African American Civil Rights movement, and LGBTQ+ activism.

The response argues that new economic opportunities were the primary cause of changes in womens roles. It then qualifies that argument by providing evidence about continued economic and social inequality such as income gaps between men and women and difference among women by race and ethnicity.

The response argues that new economic opportunities were the primary cause of changes in womens roles. It then qualifies the argument with evidence that periods of economic uncertainty following World War II and beginning in the 1970s with stagflation also played a role by forcing more women to take jobs to help families make ends meet.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about how the United States developed a national identity between 1800 and 1855.
o.af:
Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

During the first half of the 19th century, Americans were able to develop a unified national identity to a large extent. Specifically, by drawing distinctions against the British after the War of 1812 and identifying uniquely American national values, the U.S. started to move away from seeing itself primarily as a collection of states. (Establish a line of reasoning that evaluates the topic of the prompt with analytic categories)

The U.S. was developing a unified national identity by embracing the ideals of the founding documents, individuality, and voting rights. (Establish a line of reasoning with analytic categories)

After 1800, the United States developed a national identity by continuing to break away from British identity. (Establish a line of reasoning)

The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not use at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about how the United States developed a national identity between 1800 and 1855.

The Erie Canal helped to link Americans in the Northeast and the Midwest, especially through increased commercial interactions like the grain trade, which contributed to the growth of regional connections. (Uses a piece of evidence beyond the documents to make a connection to a larger argument about how increased commercial connection contributed to the growth of national identity)

VR598750_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR598750_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

[Document 2]: In seeking to rally the country to war in 1812, Congress purpose was to drive pro-war sentiment by appealing to the injuries inflicted on the country by Great Britain, which contributed to the growth of a sense of national identity in the United States. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the growth of national identity.)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

[Document 5]: Stewarts perspective as a free African American woman, especially her appeal to national heroes such as George Washington, shows the growth of national identity across different groups in the United States beyond White Americans. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that addresses the spread of national identity to different ethnic and racial groups.)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

[Document 3]: In the early 1800s manufacturing grew as Americans increasingly produced goods for sale. Madison advocated for roads and canals, in part to help move these goods around the country which created a greater feeling of national unity in many areas of the country. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how commerce strengthened national identity.)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

[Document 4]: The appeal of the Cherokee to United States audiences, especially government officials, by modeling the language of their government documents on the United States Constitution showed that the Cherokee strategized how to appeal to Americans based on their national identity. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that addresses how American national identity grew from the perspective of Native American nations.)

o.d:

VR598750_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR598750_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how the United States developed a national identity between 1800 and 1855.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

The response argues that the development of national identity was widespread, reaching multiple regions of the country. It corroborates that argument with relevant and insightful evidence from multiple variables such as how greater connections created by canals and railroads during the market revolution linked regions economically, culturally, and politically.

The response argues that military conflicts in North America contributed to the growth of American national identity. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that debates over how to manage new territory acquired through warfare, especially whether to allow the expansion of slavery, counteracted nationalism with sectional sentiment.

The response argues that while there was a limited sense of national identity in the period from 1800 to 1855 rooted in the acceptance of democratic ideals and a strong central government. It then modifies this argument with evidence that these elements of national identity actually predate 1800. The response claims that the foundations of national unity are instead found in the Revolutionary period and early republic.

o.d: The response demonstrates a complex understanding of how the United States developed a national identity between 1800 and 1855, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.

The response argues that military conflicts in North America contributed to the growth of American national identity. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that debates over how to manage new territory acquired through warfare, especially whether to allow the expansion of slavery, counteracted nationalism with sectional sentiment.

It then modifies this argument with evidence that these elements of national identity actually predate 1800. The response claims that the foundations of national unity are instead found in the Revolutionary period and early republic.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the causes of population movement to colonial British America in the period from 1607 to 1754.
o.af:
Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

While the desire for religious freedom played an important role in population movement to colonial British America, economic incentives served as the primary incentive for both voluntary and forced migration to the region between 16071754. (Establish a line of reasoning that evaluates the topic of the prompt with analytic categories)

Both the desire for religious freedom and the desire for economic opportunities encouraged people to migrate to the American colonies. (Establish a line of reasoning with analytic categories)

VR598751_rubric_category_5.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the causes of population movement to colonial British America in the period from 1607 to 1754.
o.af:

The response argues that, while the desire for religious freedom played an important role in population movement to colonial British America, economic incentives served as the primary incentive for both voluntary and forced migration to the region between 16071754. It then corroborates that argument with evidence from multiple variables such as the motives and economic activities of White settlers as well as evidence about the growth of the slave trade.

The response argues that most people migrated to America seeking religious freedom and economic opportunities. It then qualifies that argument with evidence about how different groups and colonies weighted either religious freedom or economic opportunity more than the other.

The response argues that the pursuit of religious freedom primarily drove population movement to the colonies. It then qualifies the argument with evidence that the Massachusetts colony quickly shifted to emphasizing commerce and Boston rapidly became an important trading port which in some ways changed the reasons for migration.

Discussing similarities and differences between the African American Great Migration and the movement of urban dwellers to the suburbs.

Examples of acceptable use of historical reasoning:

Innovations such as the automobile, airplane travel, and air conditioning encouraged increased population movement to the American Southwest. (Indicates a cause of internal migration to the Southwest)

VR598753_rubric_category_5.ti: Part D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR598753_rubric_category_5.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the causes of internal migration within the United States in the period from 1900 to 1970.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating complex understanding might include:

The response argues that the allure of economic opportunities served as the main reason for these population movements. It then corroborates that argument with evidence from multiple variables about multiple population movements such as the African American Great Migration, the movement of people in pursuit of war industry jobs, the movement of people to the Sun Belt, and the movement of people from cities to suburbs.

The response argues that the allure of economic opportunities served as the main reason for these population movements. It then qualifies that argument by pointing out and providing evidence that while economic opportunity was significant for all groups, racism was also an important factor for some segments of the population, both motivating and preventing migration.

The response argues that economic opportunity, climate, and discrimination contributed to internal migration. It then modifies the argument by claiming that internal migration was not a significant development in this period, providing evidence that most Americans did not in fact migrate between 1900 to 1970.

o.d: The response demonstrates a complex understanding of the causes of internal migration within the United States in the period from 1900 to 1970, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent of change in the relationship between Native Americans and the United States government from 1850 to 1900.
o.af:
Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Between 1850 and 1900, Native Americans attempted to adapt to US expansion through an increased militancy to protect their lands and their lifestyles but also through efforts to convince White Americans of the justice of their cause. However, to some extent, Native Americans reaction to U.S. expansion was a continuation of their reactions to European colonization and the 1830 Indian Removal Act. (Establish a line of reasoning that evaluates the topic of the prompt with analytic categories)

  • By 1900 the relationship between Native Americans and the United States government evolved because of warfare, removal policies, and forced assimilation. (Establish a line of reasoning with analytic categories)

  • The U.S. government increasingly tried to assimilate Indigenous Americans. (Establish a line of reasoning) [Minimally acceptable thesis/claim]

o.d: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the relationship between Native Americans and the United States government from 1850 to 1900.
o.af:
Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • European colonization

  • Seven Years War (17561763)

  • Indian Removal Act (1830)

  • Manifest Destiny/western expansion

  • Mexican-American War (1846-1848)

  • Civil War (1861-1865)

  • Second Industrial Revolution

Examples that earn this point include:

  • During the colonial period, British colonists sought to acquire Native American land either through warfare or through treaty negotiations.

  • Andrew Jackson set the stage for the future relationship of the United States government with Native Americans by enforcing the Indian Removal Act (1830), which forced Native American nations in the Southeast to leave their homelands and relocated them to western reservations.

  • A push for westward migration pushed Natives off their land, displacing them predominately under the Jackson Administration. [Minimally acceptable contextualization]

VR733766_rubric_category_3.ti: PART C2: SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
VR733766_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

  • [Document 2]: Geronimo reported that after White surveyors came to their land, conflict later broke out between the Apache and White miners and soldiers, which shows that increased White settlement in the West led to more conflict with Native Americans in the late 1800s. (Uses evidence from Document 2 to support an argument about the violent conflict between Native American peoples and the United States)

o.d:
The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least four documents.

VR733766_rubric_category_4.ti: PART C3: EVIDENCE  EVIDENCE BEYOND THE DOCUMENTS
VR733766_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not use at least one additional piece of specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the extent of change in the relationship between Native Americans and the United States government from 1850 to 1900.
o.af:
Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • Homestead Act (1862)

  • Sand Creek Massacre (1864)

  • Transcontinental railroads

  • Battle of Little Big Horn (1876)

  • Helen Hunt Jackson/Century of Dishonor

  • Bison

  • Sitting Bull

  • Chief Joseph

  • Crazy Horse

  • Dawes Severalty Act (1887)

  • Carlisle School

  • Wounded Knee massacre (1890)

Examples of acceptable pieces of evidence:

  • By passing the Homestead Act, the US government helped White settlers acquire western land, which increased settler migration to the West, leading to increased conflicts with Native Americans and more aggressive action by the government to suppress Indigenous resistance and to dispossess Indigenous people of their land. (Uses a piece of evidence beyond the documents to make a connection to a larger argument about how settler colonization led to increased United States government efforts to acquire Native American land)

  • After the Wounded Knee massacre, violent resistance to the United States by Native Americans generally ended, and the United States government had greater power in the West compared to the earlier 1800s when some Native nations had been powerful empires. (Uses a piece of evidence beyond the documents to make a connection to a larger argument about the United States military subjugation of Native Americans on the Great Plains)

o.d:

  • This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. Typically, statements credited as contextualization will be more general statements that place an argument or a significant portion of it in a broader context.

  • Statements credited as supporting evidence beyond the documents will typically be more specific details that function as support for a particular point made in an argument, analogous to the function of evidence drawn from the documents.

VR733766_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR733766_rubric_category_5.s:

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

  • [Document 4]: From the point of view of the government officials in Document 4, Native American resistance in the West could be blamed on the incomplete assimilation of Native Americans into United States society, which led the United States to change its relationship with Native American further by seeking to end the sovereignty of their nations and forcibly integrate them more fully into the nation. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that the United States sought more control over Native American people after 1850)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

  • [Document 3]: By including many workers laying track as the train moves forward, the artist of the image likely sought to show the expansion of the United States as a triumph of technological progress, replacing the less advanced Native Americans who look on. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that the United States sought to more aggressively displace Native Americans in the West between 1850 and 1900)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

  • [Document 5]: The situation of Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins was that expanded United States settlement into Nevada led to competition for land and violent conflict; she sought to appeal to the professed values of White Christians to improve the situation of Native peoples who were supposed to receive services managed by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument that Native Americans sought to find ways to use new United States government institutions created to govern the West to the benefit of Native peoples)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

  • [Document 6]: Masse-Hadjos audience was White American readers, whom he sought to accuse of hypocrisy by criticizing Native American religion while they took actions against Native American people that violated the tenets of Christianity. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that Native Americans sought to assert their own cultural practice in the face of forced assimilation by the United States)

o.d:

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

  • Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent of change in the relationship between Native Americans and the United States government from 1850 to 1900.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • The response argues that the United States federal government gained more control over Native Americans with military victories taking their territory. It then corroborates the argument of control across themes of culture in boarding schools and administration through government agencies.

  • The response argues that the United States sought to gain more control over Native American land in the West through the creation of the reservation system. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that this was largely a continuation of previous policies pursued by the United States in the eastern portion of the country in the early 1800s.

  • The response argues that the United States militarily defeated Native American resistance in the late 1800s and attempted to assimilate Native American communities. It then qualifies the argument with evidence that Native Americans continued to preserve their societies and cultures using new tactics after military defeat and despite assimilationist policies.

  • The response argues that Native Americans' relationship with the United States government remained oppositional throughout the period. It makes this argument from a military perspective, utilizing documents 1 and 2, as well as a discussion of Red Clouds War. The response also argues that the federal governments relationship with Native American culture remained oppositional throughout the period, utilizing documents 5, 6 and 7, as well as a discussion of the Dawes Act.

  • Before 1620, there were many wars fought over religion in Europe. [Minimally acceptable contextualization]

VR733767_rubric_category_5.ti: Part D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR733767_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

  • Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

  • Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent to which religion influenced social change in British North America between 1620 and 1754.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • The response argues that the Great Awakening contributed to greater beliefs in self-government. It then corroborates that argument with evidence about how the ideas of the Great Awakening led to greater self-determination in religion, especially among believers of new evangelical religions, like Methodists and Baptists, who rejected more hierarchical established churches.

  • The response argues that religious pluralism inspired many colonists to be more tolerant of people with different religious beliefs. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that colonists did not seek to respect Native American religious beliefs and instead sought to convert them to Christianity.

  • The response acknowledges that religion inspired many colonists to seek refuge in British America from persecution in Europe. It then modifies the argument with evidence that British North American colonial growth and development ultimately depended more on the pursuit of wealth than it did on religious fervor.

  • The response argues that religion brought social groups closer together in British North America. It demonstrates how the sermons of Jonathan Edwards and travels of George Whitfield created a shared religious experience for colonists throughout British North America. It then goes on to argue that the First Great Awakening also created more opportunities for women and African Americans in religious spaces, while noting that despite their increased presence in religious services, women and African Americans were rarely granted leadership roles.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent to which antislavery activists influenced social change in the United States from 1830 to 1860.

  • The response argues that political compromises over the westward expansion of slavery contributed to growing support in the North for antislavery social reform. It then corroborates that argument with evidence about how economic ties between Northern industries and Southern cotton production also inspired antislavery sentiment.

  • The response argues that antislavery activists helped grow the abolitionist movement by using religious arguments as a way to convince audiences. It then qualifies that argument with evidence that pro-slavery activists also used religious appeals to defend the institution and blunt antislavery sentiment.

  • The response argues that from a political perspective the Dred Scott case demonstrates that abolitionist activism was limited even in the North and unsuccessful at ending slavery prior to 1860. It then modifies the argument with evidence that from a practical perspective African American activism to assist enslaved people through the Underground Railroad and to publicize the brutality of slavery helped weaken the institution and make its expansion controversial.

  • Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent to which the conservative movement influenced political change in the United States from 1968 to 2001.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • The response argues that conservatives were most successful in convincing the public that the size of government was too large. It then corroborates that argument with evidence of Republican and Democratic presidents reducing the size of social programs like welfare.

  • The response argues that political conservatives sought to directly confront the communist nations through increased military spending. It then qualifies that argument with evidence of how President Nixon used diplomacy to reduce tensions with the Peoples Republic of China.

  • The response argues that conservative politicians gained support for reducing the size of the government. It then qualifies the argument with evidence that government spending increased in the 1980s.

  • The response uses evidence regarding Reagan and Clinton era policies to argue that the conservative movement successfully influenced political change on an economic policy. It also uses evidence to demonstrate that the conservative movement was less successful in influencing the government to pass conservative social policies.

o.d: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which commercial development changed United States society from 1800 to 1855.
o.af:
Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • British regulations (Navigation Acts)

  • Articles of Confederation

  • Constitution

  • First Great Awakening

  • War of 1812

  • Manifest Destiny

  • The Civil War

  • The Second Industrial Revolution

  • The Gilded Age

  • Western expansion and debates over slavery

Example of acceptable contextualization:

  • When the United States was a colony of Britain, the Navigation Acts made it so that the colonists couldnt manufacture things. In the early 1800s, many people wanted to encourage the development of manufacturing to fix this so that the country could be more economically independent.

  • The Constitution was an attempt to create a government that had more authority over the economy. [Minimally acceptable contextualization]

VR734031_rubric_category_3.s:

To earn this point, the response must accurately describerather than simply quotethe content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

o.d: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
o.af:
Example of supporting an argument using the content of a document:

  • [Document 4]: The development of textile factories like those in Unionville broke with existing social expectations, especially for middle-class women, that women should not work outside of domestic settings. (Uses evidence from Document 4 to support an argument about changing gender norms during the market revolution)

To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not use at least one additional piece of specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the extent to which commercial development changed United States society from 1800 to 1855.
o.af:
Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • Louisiana Purchase

  • Henry Clay

  • American System

  • Embargo Act (1807)

  • Era of Good Feelings

  • Boom-bust cycles

  • Panic of 1837

  • Urbanization

  • Eli Whitney/use of cotton gin

  • Market revolution

  • Second Great Awakening

  • Domestic slave trade

  • Andrew Jackson

  • Bank of the United States

  • California Gold Rush

  • Woman suffrage movement

  • Seneca Falls Convention

  • Elizabeth Cady Stanton

  • Sectionalism

  • Nativism/Know-Nothing Party

  • King Cotton

Example of evidence beyond the documents relevant to an argument about the prompt:

  • Henry Clay proposed the American System because many places needed better transportation to facilitate commerce. But federal funding for new roads and canals was controversial for political leaders who felt it was not the role of the federal government, and most internal improvements were taken by the states. (Uses a piece of evidence beyond the documents to make a connection about debates over internal improvements)

  • Statements credited as supporting evidence beyond the documents will typically be more specific details that function as support for a particular point made in an argument, analogous to the function of evidence drawn from the documents.

VR734031_rubric_category_5.ti: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  SOURCING
VR734031_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

o.d: The response does not explain how or why the documents point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
o.af:
Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents point of view:

  • [Document 1]: The report from the churches in Connecticut was written from the perspective of a temperance reformer likely influenced by the spread of the second Great Awakening. The fact that they are making recommendations to businesspeople like manufacturers shows how culture and business were linked in this period. (Provides sourcing regarding the point of view of the document relevant to an argument that religion and business practices influenced each other in this period)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the documents purpose:

  • [Document 4]: Nason tells his parents why it is so bad to have children working in the factories. He describes how harmful it is to children so that his parents will tell others not to send kids to work in the mills. He shows the bad effects of industrialization. (Provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the document relevant to an argument that commercial development produced some negative social effects)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a document:

  • [Document 7]: During the 1840s, the westward expansion of slavery contributed to the development of free-soil arguments against slavery that emphasized the ill effects of the institution for free laborers in the North noted in North Star. (Provides sourcing regarding the historical situation of the document relevant to an argument about the role of commercial development in antislavery movements)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

  • [Document 2]: The audience for Document 2 included people seeking to use steam power to speed up transportation on water, through the use of steamboats, and over land, using railroads, so as to expand the commercial development of the United States. (Provides sourcing regarding the audience of the document relevant to an argument that new technologies were used to facilitate the commercial development of the United States)

o.d:

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

VR734031_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR734031_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

  • A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

  • Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

  • Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent to which commercial development changed United States society from 1800 to 1855.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • The response argues that commercial development in the nineteenth century led to greater economic connections across the United States which contributed to the growth of a national culture. It then corroborates that argument across regions by explaining how new transportation networks increased economic and cultural connections between the Northeast and Midwest while at the same time, rising cotton production created new economic and political ties between the South and the Northeast during the first half of the 1800s.

  • The response argues that the social effects of commercial development led to the growth of reform movements. It then qualifies the argument with evidence that many people developed arguments to justify the social impacts of the growth of commerce, such as the expansion of slavery and the increased use of wage laborers in factories.

  • The response argues that the growth of a national market through transportation and communication improvements by the 1850s led to greater unity in the United States. It then modifies that argument with evidence of increased conflict over the institution of slavery connected to the development of commerce in the United States.

  • The response argues that commercial development changed American society from a religious perspective and from a class perspective. It supports the religious component of its argument with document 1 and outside evidence regarding the Burned Over District. The response also supports its argument about commercial developments effect on class with evidence from documents 4, 5, 6 and 7.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which the growth of transatlantic trade changed British North American colonial society from 1607 to 1776.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The most significant and lasting impact of the growth of transatlantic trade was the increase in the racial, religious, and ethnic diversity of the colonies, while another important but less significant impact was the Anglicization of colonial society. (Establish a line of reasoning that evaluates the topic of the prompt with analytic categories)

  • The growth of trade in the Atlantic led to the spread of Enlightenment ideas and debates about British taxes, both of which contributed to the movement for independence. (Establish a line of reasoning with analytic categories)

  • The growth of transatlantic trade led to more slavery in the colonies. (Establish a line of reasoning) [Minimally acceptable thesis/claim]

VR734032_rubric_category_1.s:

To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which the growth of transatlantic trade changed British North American colonial society from 1607 to 1776.
o.af:
Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • Native American society before the colonization of North America

  • Spanish (or other European) colonization before 1600

  • The economic motivations for exploration

  • Initial British colonization of North America in the 1600s

  • East Asia trade (e.g., tea)

  • Imperial competition among European powers

  • The Revolutionary War

Example of acceptable contextualization:

  • The Spanish and Portuguese established large profitable colonies in the Americas before the English successfully founded a permanent settlement at Jamestown. The wealth of these early Spanish and Portuguese colonies from things like silver inspired other European countries to start colonies and eventually led to massive trade in the Atlantic.

  • Explorers for European empires hoped to find a water passage to Asia through North America. [Minimally acceptable contextualization]

  • Explorers for European empires hoped to find a water passage to Asia through North America. [Minimally acceptable contextualization]

VR734032_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn the first point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.

o.d: The response does not use historical reasoning (e.g., comparison, causation, continuity and change over time) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the extent to which the growth of transatlantic trade changed British North American colonial society from 1607 to 1776.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable use of historical reasoning:

  • Early on, tobacco proved to be a very profitable crop for the Virginia colony in transatlantic trade. This created a demand for labor which at first brought in a significant number of European indentured servants and later enslaved Africans. (Indicates a change resulting from transatlantic trade.)

o.d: The response uses historical reasoning (e.g., comparison, causation, continuity and change over time) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the extent to which the growth of transatlantic trade changed British North American colonial society from 1607 to 1776.
o.af:
Examples of using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument might include the following:

  • Explaining how transatlantic trade caused the spread of plantation agriculture that led to an increase in slavery.

  • Discussing how transatlantic trade led to an increase in the presence of different European religious and ethnic groups which contributed to a significant degree of pluralism and intellectual exchange.

Examples of acceptable use of historical reasoning:

  • Early on, tobacco proved to be a very profitable crop for the Virginia colony in transatlantic trade. This created a demand for labor which at first brought in a significant number of European indentured servants and later enslaved Africans. (Indicates a change resulting from transatlantic trade.)

VR734032_rubric_category_5.ti: Part D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING  COMPLEXITY
VR734032_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

  • Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

  • Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent to which the growth of transatlantic trade changed British North American colonial society from 1607 to 1776.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • The response argues that transatlantic trade led to a steady increase in the diversity of colonial society from 1607 to 1776. The response corroborates this argument with evidence from across themes about how various factors like cultural exchange, economic incentives, and imperial competition contributed to this steady increase in diversity over time.

  • The response argues that British attempts to regulate transatlantic trade led to a decreasing loyalty to Britain in colonial society that culminated in the Declaration of Independence. The response then qualifies that argument with evidence of a gradual Anglicization of colonial society that in some ways brought the colonies and Britain closer.

  • The response argues that transatlantic trade changed the ethnic, racial, and religious makeup of the colonies. It then qualifies that argument with evidence of demographic continuities including a consistent Native American presence and constant migration from Britain.

o.d: The response demonstrates a complex understanding of the extent to which the growth of transatlantic trade changed British North American colonial society from 1607 to 1776, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.
o.af:
Examples of acceptably demonstrating a complex understanding might include:

  • The response argues that transatlantic trade led to a steady increase in the diversity of colonial society from 1607 to 1776. The response corroborates this argument with evidence from across themes about how various factors like cultural exchange, economic incentives, and imperial competition contributed to this steady increase in diversity over time.

  • The response argues that British attempts to regulate transatlantic trade led to a decreasing loyalty to Britain in colonial society that culminated in the Declaration of Independence. The response then qualifies that argument with evidence of a gradual Anglicization of colonial society that in some ways brought the colonies and Britain closer.

  • The response argues that transatlantic trade changed the ethnic, racial, and religious makeup of the colonies. It then qualifies that argument with evidence of demographic continuities including a consistent Native American presence and constant migration from Britain.

To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which changes in United States foreign policy contributed to territorial growth from 1840 to 1898.
o.af:
Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • While the foreign policy of the early republic contributed to significant territorial expansion with the Louisiana Purchase, once ideas associated with Manifest Destiny started to motivate U.S. foreign policy, there was a massive expansion that took the U.S. all the way to the Philippines. (Establish a line of reasoning that evaluates the topic of the prompt with analytic categories)

  • Changes in U.S. foreign policy contributed to the Louisiana Purchase, the annexation of Texas, the Mexican cession, and the taking of areas further away like Alaska and Hawaii. (Establish a line of reasoning with analytic categories)

  • Americans used Manifest Destiny to justify taking more land. (Establish a line of reasoning) [Minimally acceptable thesis/claim]
